questions.question: If the speed of an object is doubled, its kinetic energy increases by a factor of:
questions.explanation: $KE \propto v^2$, so doubling speed quadruples KE.

questions.question: Kinetic energy is best defined as:
options: The energy stored in an object due to its position.
The energy an object possesses due to its motion.
The force required to move an object.
The rate at which work is done.
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is the energy of motion.

questions.question: Kinetic energy is a __________ quantity and can __________ be negative.
questions.explanation: KE is scalar and always positive (depends on $v^2$).

questions.question: Two cars, A and B, have the same mass. Car A is traveling North at $25 \text{ m/s}$ and Car B is traveling East at $25 \text{ m/s}$. Which statement is true?
options: Car A has more kinetic energy because North is a positive direction.
Car B has more kinetic energy.
They have the same kinetic energy because KE is a scalar.
They have different kinetic energies because their velocities are different.
questions.explanation: KE depends only on speed magnitude, not direction.

questions.question: The Work-Energy Theorem states that the net work done on an object is equal to:
options: The change in the object's kinetic energy.
The force multiplied by the time of impact.

questions.question: A car slams on its brakes and skids to a stop. The work done by friction is _________ and the change in kinetic energy is _________.
questions.explanation: Friction opposes motion ⇒ negative work. Car stops ⇒ KE decreases ⇒ negative $\Delta KE$.

questions.question: Which of the following is an equivalent unit to the Joule (J)?
When a car's speed triples ($3v$), its stopping distance (assuming constant braking force) becomes:
questions.explanation: $F \cdot d = \frac{1}{2}mv^2$, so $d \propto v^2$. Triple speed ⇒ 9 times distance.

questions.question: What is the kinetic energy of a $0.5 \text{ kg}$ ball moving at $4 \text{ m/s}$?
A $2000 \text{ kg}$ truck has a kinetic energy of $10,000 \text{ J}$. What is its speed?

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered kinetic energy concepts.

scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2$ and its implications.
